paragraph.docTitle: Phaeosphspirone (1/1 ′ ), a pair of unique polyketide enantiomers with an unusual 6/5/5/6 tetracyclic ring from the desert plant endophytic fungus Phaeosphaeriaceae sp.

subSection.paragraph: Phaeosphspirone
Absolute configurations
Biosynthetic pathway
Cytotoxicity
ABSTRACT

Phaeosphspirone, an undescribed polyketide with a unique 6/5/5/6-fused tetracyclic system, and two known analogues, herbarin and O -methylherbarin, were purified from the endophytic fungus Phaeosphaeriaceae sp. isolated from the desert plant
Bassia dasyphylla
. The connectivity and relative configuration of phaeosphspirone was elucidated by comprehensive HR-ESI-MS and NMR analysis together with a computer-assisted structure elucidation (CASE) method. A pair of enantiomers existing in phaeosphspirone were separated by HPLC chromatography after reacting with chiral reagents, from which the absolute configuration of phaeosphspirone was simultaneously determined based on Mosher’ s rule. This tandem strategy provides a useful approach for the separation and stereochemical determination of enantiomers possessing secondary hydroxyl groups. The structural feature of phaeosphspirone, herbarin and O -methylherbarin together with gene cluster analysis suggested their polyketide biosynthetic origin. Herbarin and O -methylherbarin exhibited moderate cytotoxicity against three cancer cell lines.

footnote.paragraph: * Corresponding author. ** Corresponding author. Biology Institute, Qilu University of Technology (Shandong Academy of Sciences), Shandong, Jinan, 250103, People’ s Republic of China . E-mail addresses: zhangygcq@163.com (Y.-G. Zhang), gding@implad.ac.cn (G. Ding).

caption.paragraph: 1 H and 13 C NMR spectroscopic data of phaeosphspirone in DMSO‑ d 6

tr.th: δ ( J in Hz) a H

subSection.paragraph: The molecular formula of phaeosphspirone was determined to be C H O via HRESIMS (m/z 373.0898, [M+Na] + , calcd. 373.0899, Δ 17 18 8 0.1 mmu), with nine degrees of unsaturation. The 1 H, 13 C and HSQC NMR data of phaeosphspirone ( Table 1 and Figs. S1-S 4 , S7-S9) revealed the presence of 17 carbons, including four methyls (three methyl ethers), one oxymethylene, one oxymethine, three tetra-substituted carbons, one 1, 2, 4, 6-substituted phenyl ring, and two carbonyl carbons ( δ =199.2, 192.7), which accounted for all the 1 H and 13 C NMR C resonances except for a hydroxyl group (d, δ H = 6.88, J = 4.8 Hz in DMSO‑ d 6 ). This demonstrated that 1 possessed three additional rings aside from the phenyl ring. The 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations revealed that the hydroxyl group was connected to H-3 ( Fig. 2 and Fig. S5 ), and the remaining phaeosphspirone connectivity was completely elucidated from the HMBC spectrum ( Fig. 2 and Fig. S6, S10 ). The HMBC correlations from H-7 to C-5, C-6, C-8, C-9 and C-11 and H-9 to C-7, C-8, C-10 and C-11 together with those of the two methoxyls ( δ H =3.86, 3.87) to C-8 and C-10 established a 1, 2, 4, 6-substituted phenyl ring with a ketogroup (C-5, δ C =192.5) connected to C-6, and two methoxyls connected with C-8 and C-10, respectively. The HMBC correlations from 1-Me to C-2 and C-3; 3-OH to C-2, C-3 and C-4; H-3 to C-4 and C-13; and 14- CH 2 - to C-2, C-4 and C-13 confirmed the existence of a dihydro- 2H -pyran-3( 4H )- one ring with a methyl and a hydroxyl group connected with C-2 and C-3, respectively. The correlation of H-3 with C- 5 in the HMBC spectrum demonstrated that C-5 was connected to C-4. The quaternary carbon C-12 possessed methyl ethers based on the correlation from –OMe ( δ H = 3.25) to C-12. The key long-range HMBC correlation of H-9 to C-12 confirmed that C-11 was connected to C-12. According to the molecular formula, only an oxygen atom remained. Analysis of the chemical shift values of C-2 ( δ C =108.4) and C-12 ( δ C =109.6) demonstrated that C-2 was connected to C-12 by an ether bond to form another furan ring. Although there were no HMBC correlations from H-3 to C-12 (this might be because the dihedral degree between H-3 with C-12 is close to 90 ◦ C, leading to no HMBC correlations observed), considering the degrees of unsaturation, C-4 was suggested to be connected with C-12, which created a hexahydro-2,5a-methanocyclopenta[ d ][1,3]dioxepine skeleton (6/5/6/5 tetracyclic system).

paragraph.tableNote: 1 H-NMR was recorded at 600 MHz; 13 C-NMR was recorded at 150 MHz.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 2. Key 2 D-NMR correlations and NOE spectral analysis of phaeosphspirone.

subSection.paragraph: To support this conclusion, computer-assisted structure elucidation (CASE) was used to analyse the NMR data of phaeosphspirone. CASE, as a technological development, was developed in recent years to overcome obstacles in NMR data interpretation ( Elyashberg et al., 2010 , 2013 ; Moser et al., 2012 ; Naman et al., 2015 ; Ding et al., 2021 ). ACD/Structure Elucidator was used to resolve the uncertain connection of C-4 with C-12, which gave 519 candidates filtered from 126,650 isomers in 2 min 2 s from the MCD (molecular connectivity diagram). The top ten candidates were generated by ACD/Structure Elucidator. Structure ranking is based on the overall differences between experimental and predicted 13 C chemical shifts ( Fig. 3 ). The lower the value ( dN ( 13 C)-neural network and dA ( 13 C)-HOSE), the better the ranking. Atom colour coding is based on the individual atom difference between experimental and predicted 13 C chemical shifts. The green colour represents a difference between 0 and 3 ppm, and the yellow colour is > 3–15 ppm. Structures ranking 1–4 display “the same flat structures” as that of phaeosphspirone but with different atom/NMR shift assignments. Thus, according to the calculated CASE results together with NMR data analysis, the planar structure of phaeosphspirone was established.

The optical rotation of phaeosphspirone was near zero, implying that a pair of enantiomers ( 1 / 1 ′ ) might exist for this compound. It was difficult to obtain enough enantiomers by chiral column separation due to the limited amounts of enantiomers ( 1 / 1 ′ ). Considering a secondary hydroxyl group in the structure of phaeosphspirone, if chiral reagents (such as Mosher’ s reagents) are mixed with phaeosphspirone ( 1 / 1 ′ ), theoretically, two diastereomers would be generated, which could then be separated using an HPLC column (C 18 ). This approach could also determine the stereochemistry of C-3 based on Mosher’ s rule. Reactions of phaeosphspirone ( 1 / 1 ′ ) with ( R )-MTPA-Cl will form the corresponding S -MTPA ester ( 1a and 1 ′ a ), and reactions of phaeosphspirone ( 1 / 1 ′ ) with ( S )-MTPA-Cl will form the corresponding R -MTPA ester ( 1b and 1 ′ b ) ( Ohtani et al., 1991 ). As expected, two peaks were observed in the corresponding HPLC profiles (Supporting Information ). This demonstrated that a pair of enantiomers existed in phaeosphspirone. According to Mosher’ s rule, the difference in chemical shifts (Δ
δSR
=
δS - δR
) for 1a and 1b assigned the C- 3 in 1 / 1 ′ to be S / R ( Fig. 4 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 1. Structures of phaeosphspirone ( 1 / 1 ′), herbarin ( 2 ) and O -methylherbarin ( 3 ).
Fig. 3. Top ten phaeosphspirone ( 1 / 1 ′) candidates generated by ACD/Structure Elucidator.

subSection.paragraph:
The structural features of herbarin ( 2 ), O -methylherbarin ( 3 ) and phaeosphspirone imply that compounds 1–3 originate from nonreducing polyketide synthases (NR-PKSs) ( Studt et al., 2012 ). The genome of this fungus was then sequenced and shown to possess eight reducing polyketide synthase (HR-PKSs and PR-PKSs) and four nonreducing polyketide synthase (NR-PKS) gene clusters. Bioinformatics and phylogenetic analysis revealed that an NR-PKS gene cluster in scaffold3 ( sgp cluster) of Phaeosphaeriaceae sp. is hypothesized to be the polyketide product (phaeosphspirone) of
Fusarium fujikuroi
fsr1 (gene cluster of fusarubin) ( Fig. 5 and Fig. S18-S20). The multimodular polyketide synthases fsr1 and sgpC have the same domains, including SAT, KS, AT, PT, ACP and R. Further analysis of the conserved active sites of fsr1 and sgpC shows that these domains are all active (Fig. S21). The predicted proteins in the sgp cluster include SgpC (NR-PKSs), SgpB and SgpF ( O -methyltransferases); SgpE (cytochrome P450 monooxygenase); and two Baeyer Villiger monooxygenase (DUF4243) family oxidases (SgpA and SgpG), which are the key enzymes that catalyse the skeleton formation of phaeosphspirone (Fig. S22 and S23). Thus, the biosynthetic pathway of phaeosphspirone is proposed as depicted in Scheme 1. First, SgpC (PKSs), SgpB/F and SgpA/G biosynthesize herbarin ( 2 ) similar to the fsr gene cluster forming fusarubin ( Studt et al., 2012 ). Then, Baeyer-Villiger oxidation (SgpA or SgpG) leads herbarin ( 2 ) to produce compound ( 4 ), after which addition and dehydration (which might be spontaneous) form intermediate ( 5 ). Further oxidation (SgpE) of ( 5 ) at C-3 generates compound ( 6 ), and phaeosphspirone is finally formed by methylation (SgpB/F) of compound ( 6 ). The biosynthesis of phaeosphspirone is currently under investigation.

Herbarin ( 2 ) was reported to display biological activity against PC-3 M cell lines ( Paranagama et al., 2007 ), whereas no report about bioactivities of O -methylherbarin ( 3 ) was found. The cytotoxic effects of compounds 1–3 were evaluated in three cancer cell lines, HepG2, HCT116, and B16 ( Chen et al., 2017 ). Compounds 2 and 3 exhibited cytotoxic activity with IC 50 = 4.62 ± 0.55/3.64 ± 1.21, 2.56 ± 0.67/1.22 ± 0.18, and 2.25 ± 0.06/1.97 ± 0.32 μ M, respectively, compared with the positive control cis -platin (IC 50 =21.73 ±1.10, 9.71 ± 0.11, and 16.79 ± 2.85 μ M). Unfortunately, phaeosphspirone ( 1 / 1 ′ ) did not display cytotoxic effects.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 4. Δ δ values (in ppm) =
δS - δR
for ( R )- and ( S )-MPTA diesters 1a / 1b and 1 ′ a / 1 ′b.

Fig. 5. A: Comparison of the fusarubin gene cluster fsr and phaeosphspirone gene cluster. B: Phylogenetic analysis of the phaeosphspirone gene cluster in
Phaeosphaeriaceae
sp.

subSection.paragraph: Phaeosphspirone ( 1 / 1 ′) features a unique 6/5/5/6-fused polyketide core skeleton that is not encountered in nature. Four stereocentres, including two ketal carbons (C-2 and C-12) connected by an ether linkage and eight oxygen atoms from different functionalities, including carbonyl, ether bond, –OH, -OMe and ketal groups, are present in its structure, which enhances the structural complexity of 1 / 1 ’ ( Fig. 1 ). Structurally, 1 / 1 ′ is most likely derived from pyranonaphthoquinone herbarin ( 2 ) via further oxidation, condensation and methylation. Hence, 1 / 1 ′ represents a new type of pyranonaphthoquinone-derived polyketide. The unique structure of 1 / 1 ′ further supports that endophytic fungi inhabiting desert plants are an important resource for the discovery of novel secondary metabolites. Enantiomers are mainly separated by chiral columns, and then their absolute configurations are determined. In this report, the separation and absolute determination of the enantiomer phaeosphspirone ( 1 / 1 ′) were solved through a tandem strategy, which provides a useful method for enantiomer separation and stereochemical determination. Our results further support that endophytic fungi with few chemical investigation from desert plants are a potent biological resources of new/novel secondary metabolites with a wide range of bioactivities.

Optical rotations were taken on a PerkinElmer 241 polarimeter, and UV data were recorded on a Thermo Genesys-10S UV–Vis spectrometer. The IR spectra were measured using a Nicolet IS5FT-IR spectrophotometer. 1D and 2D NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker 600 spectrometer ( 1 H: 600 MHz, 13 C: 150 MHz). HRESIMS was obtained using a TOF-ESI-MS (Waters Synapt G2, USA ). Semipreparative HPLC separation was performed on a Shimadzu LC-6AD instrument packed with a YMC-Pack ODS-A column (5 μ m, 250 × 10 mm ). Sephadex LH-20 was purchased from Pharmacia Biotech, Sweden . TLC was performed on silica gel GF254 (10–40 μ m; Qingdao Marine Chemical, Inc.). Silica gel (60–100 or 200–300 mesh) for column chromatography was produced by Qingdao Marine Chemical Factory, Qingdao, China .

The endophytic fungus Phaeosphaeriaceae sp
. (TR-4-12) was provided and identified by
Dr Bing-da Sun
from the plant
Bassia dasyphylla
(Fisch. et Mey.) O. Kuntze (Chenopodiaceae) growing in the Tengger Desert , Ningxia Province , China (Latitude: 37 ◦ 75 ′ 46 ′′ N, Longitude:
104 ◦ 57 ′ 43 ′′ E
and Elevation above sea level:
1050 m
), which was deposited at the Institute of Microbiology , Chinese Academy of Science
Scheme 1. Potential gene cluster and biogenetic pathway of phaeosphspirone.

(VOUCHER NUMBER: CGMCC3.17,737) and the Institute of Medicinal Plant Development , Peking Union Medical College and Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences (Number: TR-4-12). This fungus was identified based on the sequences of the ITS/ 5.8S regions of its ribosomal DNA, which was also referred to different references (Phookamsak et al., 2014; Helaly et al., 2018 ; Mapook et al., 2020 ; Phukhamsakda et al., 2020 ). The sequence data derived from the fungal strain have been submitted and deposited at GenBank with accession number KT347320 . BLAST search results showed that the sequence was similar (94%) to the sequence of
Stagonospora pseudovitensis
(CBS135094) in GenBank with the accession number KF251261 . The fungus was grown on PDA plates at 25 ◦ C for 7 days. Then, the fresh mycelium was inoculated into autoclaving sterilized solid medium containing rice (60.0 g) and distilled water (80 mL) in Fernbach flasks (500 mL) for further fermentation at 25 ◦ C for 40 days with 45 bottles of Fernbach flasks (500 mL).

The fermented rice substrate was extracted with EtOAc (2.5 L 4 times), and the organic solvent was evaporated to dryness under vacuum to afford 37.1 g of extract. The crude extract ( 37.1 g ) was subjected to isolation by silica gel column chromatography (CC) (10 × 11.5 cm , 200–300 mesh, 400 g ) using a petroleum ether-acetone gradient elution (50:1–0:1, each 1 L) to afford nine corresponding fractions (A–I). Fr. D ( 1.3 g ) was subjected to Sephadex LH-20 and eluted with CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH (1:1, v/v) to give five fractions (D1-D5). Fraction D3 ( 0.8 g ) was fractionated by silica gel CC (32 × 2.4 cm , 200–300 mesh, 45 g ) using a petroleum ether-acetone gradient elution (100:1–0:1, each 60 mL) to give seven fractions (D3a–D 3 g ). Fr. D3e ( 20.6 mg ) was applied to HPLC (MeOH: H 2 O =53%: 46%, 2 mL/min, 210 nm ) to afford 1 ( t R 19.5 min, 2.2 mg ).

Colourless powder (MeOH); [α] 26D +4 ( c = 0.14, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 220 (3.99), 270 (3.32), 328 (2.93) nm; IR (Neat) ν max : 2923, 1750, 1606, 1315, 955 cm 1 ; HRESIMS m/z : 373.0898 [M+Na] + (calcd. 373.0899 for C 17 H 18 O 8 ). 1 HNMR (600 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz, DMSO‑ d 6 ) see
Table S1. 1
HNMR (600 MHz, MeOD- d 4 ) and 13 C NMR (150 MHz, MeOD- d 4 ) see Table S2.

paragraph.emphasis: 4.4. Preparation of (R)- and (S)-MTPA esters of compound 1

subSection.paragraph: ( R )-MTPACl (8 μL) was added to a solution of compound 1 ( 0.5 mg ) in pyridin- d 5 (200 μL) and placed at room temperature for 24 h. The crude product was purified by HPLC (acetonitrile: H 2 O = 69%: 31%, 2 mL/min, 210 nm ) to afford ( S )-MTPA ester ( 1a ) (≈ 0.4 mg , t R = 28.42 min) and ( S )-MTPA ester ( 1 ′ a ) (≈ 0.4 mg , t R = 31.30 min). ( S )-MTPACl (8 μL) was added to a solution of compound 1 ( 0.5 mg ) in pyridin- d 5 (200 μL) and placed at room temperature for 24 h. The crude product was purified by HPLC (acetonitrile: H 2 O = 69%: 31%, 2 mL/min, 210 nm ) to afford ( R )-MTPA ester ( 1 ′ b ) (≈ 0.4 mg , t R = 28.51 min) and ( R )- MTPA ester ( 1b ) ( 0.4 mg , t R = 31.41 min). 1 H NMR data from phaeosphspirone ( 1 ) and the ( S )- and ( R )-MTPA ester derivatives of phaeosphspirone ( 1/1 ′) are shown in Table S3.

Genomic DNA of the endophytic fungus Phaeosphaeriaceae sp. was prepared according to the CTAB method. Shotgun genome sequencing was performed at Hangzhou 1 Gene Company using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 sequencing platform. The contigs were assembled by Discover and then formatted to the BLAST protein database for local BLAST search. The PKS gene clusters were predicted by antiSMASH and NCBI local BLAST 2.11.0. The coding region of the gene cluster protein was predicted by 2nd Find (http://biosyn.nih.go.jp/2ndfind) and manually checked with the online NCBI BLAST (http://blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/). The PKS domains were analysed by the Protein Conserved Domain Database (CDD) at the NCBI server and the PKS/NRPS Analysis website. NR-PKSs and their responsible polyketides were collected from the literature. The amino acid sequences of NR-PKSs were obtained from NCBI GenBank and aligned by ClustalW for phylogenetic analysis. A phylogenetic tree was constructed by the neighbour-joining method using MEGA 6.0 and is illustrated in Figure S16.
The cytotoxic activities of the isolated compounds were evaluated against the HepG2, HCT116, and B16 cell lines by the MTT colorimetric method with cis -platin as a positive control.
The authors declare no conflicts of interest.

We acknowledge financial support from key project at central government level: The ability establishment of sustainable use for valuable Chinese medicine resources (2060302-2101-18), and the National Natural Science Foundation of China (31570340 and 31670011).
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2021.112969.
